IMAGE.NAME: DSC_2180.jpg
IMAGE.CAPTION: With 800,000 residents in just 7.25sq km, Manshiet Nasser on the edge of Cairo is one of the most densely populated areas in Africa. 10th May 2007, © Jeff Black /IRIN

IMAGE.NAME: DSC_2232.jpg
IMAGE.CAPTION: Manshiet Nasser sits on the rocky spurs where Egypt's Eastern Desert Plateau meets the Nile Valley. Residents urgently need more water, sewage and refuse facilities. 10th May 2007, © Jeff Black /IRIN

IMAGE.NAME: DSC_2216.jpg
IMAGE.CAPTION: Egypt's urban population is 40 percent larger than it was 10 years ago. 14 percent of the population is under six years of age. 10th May 2007, © Jeff Black /IRIN

IMAGE.NAME: DSC_2111.jpg
IMAGE.CAPTION: New regulations will allow Manshiet Nasser residents to legally own their own houses. The land they stand on is being sold at about LE150 [US $26] per sq m. 10th May 2007, © Jeff Black /IRIN

IMAGE.NAME: DSC_2106.jpg
IMAGE.CAPTION: Narrow streets and a lack of amenities mean that rubbish from households accumulates in unhealthy heaps. 10th May 2007, © Jeff Black /IRIN

IMAGE.NAME: DSC_2130.jpg
IMAGE.CAPTION: Sewage flows from overhanging buildings destabilise the sandstone. A local girl was killed here by falling rock in 2006. 10th May 2007, © Jeff Black /IRIN

IMAGE.NAME: DSC_2219.jpg
IMAGE.CAPTION: Planners and engineers involve local people in the ongoing development process. 80 percent of the workforce for the water and sewage projects must come from Manshiet Nasser. 10th May 2007, © Jeff Black /IRIN

IMAGE.NAME: DSC_2143.jpg
IMAGE.CAPTION: Cairo Governorate officials want to see the Manshiet Nasser model developed in all the city's informal areas.. 10th May 2007, © Jeff Black /IRIN
